docs.lead_paragraph: PERHAPS the economy in 2003 will turn out to be a bit like the war in Iraq: a slow start that got the critics carping, followed by a surprisingly strong surge to the finish. The stock market's reaction to all the good news from Iraq has been something less than impressive. This week the pros who trade stock index futures overnight generally expected rallies when the stock market opened, but were disappointed by the hesitance of real investors to bid up the prices of actual stocks.

headline.main: Economy May Be Better Than You Think

docs.abstract: Floyd Norris comment holds US economy may be better than it appears; holds retail sales are growing at tepid pace, but high gasoline prices can be blamed for that; says unemployment insurance figures before seasonal adjustment show 7 percent decline; holds stocks of industries other than computers and telecommunications are performing well; graph (M)
docs.snippet: PERHAPS the economy in 2003 will turn out to be a bit like the war in Iraq: a slow start that got the critics carping, followed by a surprisingly strong surge to the finish.     The stock market's reaction to all the good news from Iraq has been...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation said today that it lost $55 million in its third quarter as payments from Medicare dropped sharply and it wrote down the value of certain hospitals. Executives warned that earnings for the rest of the year would be lower than previously expected. The quarter, ended Feb. 28, was the first in which Tenet, the nation's second-largest hospital operator, behind HCA, lost much of the revenue it had been receiving from Medicare for certain high-cost patients, known as outliers. The company has acknowledged that much of its earnings growth over the last several years stemmed from its aggressive increases in list prices, which led to unusually high outlier payments under the complicated Medicare formulas.

headline.main: Tenet Healthcare Reports $55 Million Quarterly Loss

docs.abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp lost $55 million in its third quarter ended Feb 28 as payments from Medicare dropped sharply and it wrote down value of certain hospitals; payments from Medicare dropped to $40 million from $191 million year earlier; revenue rose 5.8 percent, to $3.69 billion; chairman-chief executive Jeffrey C Barbakow comments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Corporations would find billions of dollars of pension shortfalls eliminated overnight under a proposal being prepared to address a longstanding issue in pension accounting. The proposed legislation, being drafted by a Democrat and a Republican who sponsored changes in retirement laws in 2001, would create a permanent replacement for the 30-year bond in certain pension calculations. An interim measure, allowing companies to use a more favorable rate, is set to expire at the end of the year.

headline.main: Plan to Alter A Yardstick For Pensions

docs.abstract: Corporations would find billions of dollars of pension shortfalls eliminated under legislation proposed by Reps Rob Portman and Benjamin L Cardin to address longstanding issue in pension accounting; legislation would create permanent replacement for 30-year bond in certain pension calculations; interim measure, allowing companies to use more favorable rate, is set to expire at end of year; proposal would use rate that is tied to high-rated corporate bonds and that is higher than both interim measure and rate that companies have traditionally used to measure their pension obligations; higher rate, known as discount rate, makes obligations to retirees look smaller, at least on paper; American companies had total pension shortfall of about $300 billion at end of 2002; many big companies, most notably General Motors, have said they must make billions of dollars of contributions to their plans in next few years to comply with funding requirements; company pension plans have weakened in last three years as stocks and interest rates have plummeted (M)
docs.snippet: Corporations would find billions of dollars of pension shortfalls eliminated overnight under a proposal being prepared to address a longstanding issue in pension accounting.    The proposed legislation, being drafted by a Democrat and a Republican...

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, with California suffering from rolling blackouts and oil prices sinking, energy policy was a centerpiece of the Bush administration's domestic agenda. Then the terror attacks intervened and momentum for a wide-ranging new energy program was lost. Now the House and Senate are again moving ahead on comprehensive energy measures that sponsors say are needed steps toward stability in the volatile oil and power industries. But critics say they are stuffed with special-interest aid and tax breaks for big energy companies and fail to recognize a changed energy and economic climate. One senior House Democratic aide said the House measure, with its focus on oil and gas production, was the equivalent of wearing 1970's fashions in the 21st century.

headline.main: Energy Matters Return to Fore On Capitol Hill

docs.abstract: House and Senate are moving ahead on comprehensive energy measures that sponsors say are needed steps toward stability in volatile oil and power industries; critics say they are stuffed with special-interest aid and tax breaks for big energy companies and fail to recognize changed energy and economic climate; Rep Billy Tauzin says criticism is shortsighted and new legislation is needed now; estimates measure could create 700,000 jobs; Rep Nick J Rahall II says bills would benefit big business, not consumers; House measure includes $18.7 billion in tax breaks that opponents of bill say are geared mainly to oil and gas companies and do little to promote conservation or development of new energy technologies; Public Interest Research Group director Anna Aurillo calls proposal backward-looking energy bill; House Democrats, backed by United Mine Workers of America, are fighting provision that they say could allow coal companies to escape responsibility for health benefits of future retirees by prepaying some of their health costs into benefit fund; spokesman for Rep Eric Cantor, sponsor of bill, says intent is to give some flexibility to coal companies that have run into trouble selling some of their subsidiary operations because of benefits issue; adds workers would be fully protected (M)
docs.snippet: Two years ago, with California suffering from rolling blackouts and oil prices sinking, energy policy was a centerpiece of the Bush administration's domestic agenda. Then the terror attacks intervened and momentum for a wide-ranging new energy...

docs.lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor's lowered its debt rating outlook on General Motors to negative from stable yesterday, questioning how the company will pay for its multibillion-dollar pension and health care liabilities. The credit rating agency also warned that the ratings of G.M. and Ford Motor -- both at BBB, the second-lowest investment grade -- were under constant review and could be downgraded without notice should their financial performances stumble. S.& P.'s rating outlook for Ford is also negative, but companies are typically put on credit watch before S.& P. cuts debt ratings. Scott Sprinzen, an S.& P. analyst, said pension fund issues had become a critical factor at G.M. He estimated G.M.'s pension liabilities at $23 billion to $26 billion, with health care obligations of $50 billion.

headline.main: STANDARD & POOR'S LOWERS DEBT RATING ON G.M.

docs.abstract: Standard & Poor's lowers its debt rating outlook on General Motors to negative from stable, questioning how company will pay for its pension and health liabilities (S)
docs.snippet: Standard & Poor's lowered its debt rating outlook on General Motors to negative from stable yesterday, questioning how the company will pay for its multibillion-dollar pension and health care liabilities. The credit rating agency also warned that the...

docs.lead_paragraph: During negotiations over the Kyoto Protocol, the United States preached the importance of market solutions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Few countries listened. Now, with the Americans no longer at the table, the former free-market opposition has taken over the pulpit. Canada ratified the treaty in December, meaning the plan to reduce greenhouse gases is just one nation shy of becoming law in more than 100 countries. And the heart of the treaty is an emissions-trading plan that closely resembles what the United States originally proposed.

headline.main: U.S. Left Out of Emissions Trading

docs.abstract: US is being left out of emissions trading; US preached importance of market solution to reduce greenhouse gas emissions during negotiations over Kyoto Protocol; Canada ratified treaty in December, meaning plan to reduce greenhouse gases is one nation shy of becoming law in more than 100 countries; heart of treaty is emissions-trading plan that closely resembles what US originally proposed; Steve Drummond, managing director of greenhouse gas brokerage in London calls CO2e.com, says Europe can dominate emissions trading market now that Americans are out; David Doniger, former Kyoto treaty negotiator under Pres Bill Clinton, says when Pres Bush pulled out in cavalier way he did, he galvanized everyone around world to make it work; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: United Airlines said yesterday that it had reached tentative agreements on concessions with five labor groups represented by the International Association of Machinists. But talks continued with the airline's mechanics, whose rejection in late November of wage and benefit concessions negotiated by machinist union leaders was one of several factors that pushed United toward its bankruptcy filing in early December.

headline.main: United and 5 Groups Agree on Concessions

docs.abstract: United Airlines reaches tentative agreements on concessions with five labor groups represented by International Assn of Machinists; talks continue with airline's mechanics, whose rejection in late November of wage and benefit concessions negotiated by machinist union leaders was one of several factors that pushed United toward its bankruptcy filing in early December; agreements would give United cost savings of $445 million per year for six years through changes to wages, benefits and work rules; union spokesman Joe Tiberi comments; new contracts will have 13 percent reduction in hourly wage rates, 20 percent co-payment toward cost of health insurance and work rule changes to allow more use of part-time employees (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The UnitedHealth Group and PacifiCare Health Systems, the managed care companies, have won a Supreme Court decision allowing them to send a dispute with doctors to arbitration, at least initially. An arbitrator, not a court, should first consider whether agreements between the companies and doctors bar remedies that would be available if a claim were decided in federal court, the justices ruled 8 to 0.
docs.abstract: UnitedHealth Group and PacifiCare Health Systems win Supreme Court decision allowing them to send dispute with doctors to arbitration, at least initially; court says arbitrator, not court, should first consider whether agreements between companies and doctors bar remedies that would be available if claims were decided by federal court; two managed care companies are fighting claims they violated federal racketeering law by delaying payments to doctors (S)
